p: Kamatou [ 36] assessed the antimalarial activity of three South African sage species and pointed out that the best antimalarial and anti-inflammatory activity was shown by S. runcinate EO, where Î²-caryophyllene (10.5%) was one of main compounds, as in S. aurea. The S. aurea EO used herein was ineffective on the tested virus. This could be explained, on one hand, by the fact that both malaria and influenza virus evidenced different sensitivity to this oil and, on the other hand, by the fact that the antimalaria activity may have been due to a synergic effect of other compounds [ 49, 50].
